{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3246000,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-27T06:32:25.894Z","cooked":"

I love the Rev Mini Power Module form factor for sensor power distribution, and am trying to find something similarly sized and price while they’re out of stock.

REV Robotics

Mini Power Module

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 35

Amazon has ATO/Mini fuse blocks, but I am not getting any useful results on the “ATM” fuse size used on the Rev module. I tried ordering one of the Mini fuse blocks but it’s enormous, like 5" square, super overkill.

I don’t want to put Andersons on all my 18-20awg sensor power wires, so the Andymark distribution board isn’t a great fit either. At least it’s small and I do have one on hand.

andymark.com

Powerpole Fused Distribution Board

You won't find a better power distribution setup than this board. Use it for testing intakes, arms, running small robots, and more!The best in simple power distribution is here. This board features six individually fused outputs, requiring standard...

Do you really need fuses there?

You’re not wrong, I could splice everything through one PDH slot on 18awg and call it a day since it’s all custom circuits.
I have to power 4 encoders, a pigeon, and possibly a CANivore so it’s a fair amount of distribution and wire length. I strongly prefer single fuses per device/branch for troubleshooting purposes…
